After ordering the leather back I decided I needed to modify the original "wood" back that came with my phone. After seeing how Dconn1975 wrapped his battery mod (turned out very nice), I decided to come up with a few options for the original wood back. Having zero experience with 3m wrap I decided that would not be a good option for me and if the paint doesn't work out its going in the trash anyway. So I found some bedliner paint I had left over from another project and decided to give it a try. It probably took all of 15/20 minutes for prep time and about 30 seconds to paint. Now I'm just waiting for it to dry completely so I can install. Here are a few photos of the outcome so far.

replies.text: Looks very "grippy"

I hope so. I'm being very patient right now and letting is dry completely. Maybe even a little over kill. My biggest concern is it will scratch or peel easily. I scuffed it up with a fairly rough sandpaper (I figured I could get away with due to the amount of texture in the paint) cleaned it good with alcohol and then painted. I'll post photos of it on the phone in a bit.

So I'm half way through the day and this is definitely "grippy", matter of fact it's probably closer to "tacky". It's not picking up lint or anything but if I'd tried this before I ordered the leather back, I might not have ordered it.
Very cool! I did my whole truck in bedline, and only part that is wearing is the bed where I've drug stuff and scratched it off. I think youll be happy with it.

Great now I have to go to the auto parts store and pick up a can of bed spray. See what you did. Thanks. Haha.
I have the leather back from Moto on my phone now. But I do switch and put the wood back on if I'm working or doing something where I don't want to mess up the leather. I really don't like the wood so this will be a perfect fox for me!
Thanks!

This is exactly what I was thinking. I'll use the leather on normal days and then use this for times I don't want to mess up the leather. 
You'll love the grip, it will feel a little tacky most of the time. I really like it.

Don't do it. It ends up that after two days the bed liner paint started "melting" or "pushing" into thick lines of paint in the areas where I hold the phone the most (heavy wear areas). It went from tacky to down right sticky. So I took a coarse grit sanding block to it and removed all the paint. Then a fine grit to smooth it back out. Turns out the thing is actually wood. Very thin wood laminate, but wood just the same. It now has what my crafty wife would call a little bit of a "distressed" look to it. Not really an issue and my leather back is in the hands of FedEx. It should be at my door on Wednesday the 28th.
You get my vote for the "Coolest Solution to a ZForce Situation" - a phone with a bed liner - or - a bed liner that makes phone calls.

FYI in case you don't know about the 'Restart Moto Mod' option in Settings.
I have the Tumi mod and it is configured in Efficiency Mode, meaning it keeps the phone's battery at 80%, rather than Default mode which keeps the phone's battery at 100%. This has always worked as described, until today. Today the behavior is Default, even though settings still says Efficiency. I changed the setting and then changed it back, but that didn't change the behavior. Mod SW version is 0.42 and check for updates didn't find anything newer. Then I saw the option Restart Moto Mod so I tried that - and it worked.

My Tumi battery mod starting doing they same thing last week. It always charges in default mode despite being set to Efficiency mode.
I have used Restart Moto Mod and it does not help.

It might have something to do with your permission settings. I messed around with mine and the same thing happened. Had to grant the moto mod app some deep level permissions and things went back to normal.
Uninstalling the Moto Mod app and reinstalling it seems to have fixed it.

They gave me a 30℅ discount code, Incipio. I ended up doing the buy one get one Verizon deal for the Mophie pack. I'm tempted to do that deal for the projector and camera mod but will probably resist temptation.

It's said that it's not good for phone batteries to be run down low all the time. I have the Z and am using the battery mod so the phone drains to 80% then the mod kicks in and drains to 0 before the phone starts draining from 80%. So the mod is always being run down to 0. How much will that shorten the mods life? IMO Motorola needs to add another option to the mod settings.
1 keep phone battery at 100%
2 efficiency mode
3 mod drains to 20%(or whatever would be best) then phone battery stats draining

They probably didn't want to over complicate things with too many options. The third option might be nice, though. But mostly the mod protects the phone's internal battery, while the mod is more disposable. I would guess the mod will still last 1-2+ years before it has obvious battery degradation, at which point most people won't care, or you'll be able to get another battery mod on clearance since it's for an old model.
You could simply have it keep the phone at 100% then remove the mod once the mod battery gets down to 15-20%

replies.text: But then you're degrading your internal battery. From what I've read it isn't good to keep Li-ion batteries constantly at 100%. Apparently they live longer the more their charge stays between 20-80%

title: Does the Battery Mod cause device to get hot?

thread.text: Does the Battery Mod cause device to get hot. I don't have the mod yet and my phone still gets hot during games. So I'm wondering how it will be with the mod? I'm considering picking one up. Thanks in advance for your help.
The mod most likely won't help with cooling. The heat is generated by the screen and mainly the CPU.
I know it won't help, but considering it already gets pretty warm, I'm wondering how bad it is with the mod on it charging while using the phone?

replies.text:
I don't play a lot of games but I use the battery Mod daily, and it definitely does not get as warm as my Turbo 2 used to with my usage habits. I've used it for navigation a decent amount and never noticed any additional warmth, which I have with other phones, especially when plugged in.
Here's an idea of the battery life with the MOD. I'll also warn you that it does throw off the battery stats a little. Phones do not register SOT while charging, so it loses track of SOT while the phone is getting those little bursts. In the screenshot below, I'd say there's about a 2.5 hour gap of SOT missing. So I'd say I can get about 10 hours of SOT over just shy of 2 days without any juice. That will not be the case while gaming I'm sure, but the battery life with the Mod is a real game changer for me. I used to feel that way when I first got the Droid Maxx, but this is next level.

title: Moto Mod: magnetic car dock or charging docking station?

thread.text:
Are there any car docks or nightstand charging stations that let you connect the Moto Z Play phone with the Moto Mod magnets?
Seems like it would make inserting and removing a phone from a docking station easier, if it was connected through the Moto Mod magnets, instead of lining up a USB port.
This could be used to launch special docking apps like a car mode or nightstand clock/alarm too.
My old Thunderbolt had a dock app clock that launched when it was placed in a docking station. I thought it was a handy feature.
You could glue a moto back to a car dock so the moto z play would snap into the back

replies.text: I think he's wanting charing and/or some kind of stereo integration with it, not just a mount. If mounting was all that's needed, the typical magnet mounts work with these phones well. I got this one the other day.

thread.text: Can any of the charging bscks wireless or wired be charged through USB?

replies.text:
The incipio battery pack mod with wireless charging can be charged by itself by only wireless charging . 
When mod is attached to the phone, the mod will be charged as phone is charged through USB C port, if usb port used. Internal phone battery charges, then switches to battery pack to charge via built in software. It's pretty well thought out.
It is but it doesn't help in this specific situation

title: Anyone else keeping battery mod on 24/7?

thread.text: I'm using the battery mod as part of the phone and keep it always on. Makes worrying about battery life a non-issue. Anyone else doing this and how do you like it?
Same here. I take it off after like 15 hours. Lol. Crazy.
How cool is it that we have a phone where you can basically add a magnetic backing that gives another 2200mah in battery? I'm loving having that option.

replies.text: It really is! For me I don't use it as an option but is always on. It helps immensely with my battery OCD that the battery level icon never goes below 80%
Same. Feels awesome to not use phone battery til like 7pm..,
Using the mod do you keep the main battery at 80% or 100%?
I have it set to efficiency mode where the mod doesn't kick in until the phone battery falls to 80%.
I'm not sure I understand the benefit to that feature.
Charges less often.

Here's how I see it in my opinion: keeping the main battery constantly at 100% is probably not optimal for the battery itself. From everything I've read on the subject the sweet spot for an Li-ion battery is between 40 and 80%. So there's that. Plus by strictly using the mod to power the device (or more correctly constantly keeping the main battery fully charged) you'll probably discharge the mod (an Li-ion battery) completely on a regular basis. [Taken from the web] "One of the worst things you can do to a Li-ion battery is to run it out completely all the time. Full discharges put a lot of strain on the battery, and it's much better practice to do shallow discharges to no lower than 20 percent". 
So by using the main battery for 20% at the start, and then letting the mod do the rest you'll probably not deplete it too often which is better for the mod. The good news is that the mod is replaceable, but no sense helping it along to a quicker death . Just my two cents as I know everyone will do things that works the best for the way they use the phone.

thread.text: Good thoughts..I'll try to change to the efficiency mode.

title: Moto Battery Mod and Turbo Charger

thread.text:
Hi, I got the Moto Z Force recently and I really like it. I had a Droid 2 global followed by a Moto X (2nd gen). I find it hard to leave the moto stuff behind so I'm glad this phone feels familiar. 
I was curious about the Moto Battery Mod. I would like to get one (I've seen Tumi mostly) but wanted to ask if it was meant to be on the phone at all times? I'm not sure if there would be any detrimental effects to leaving it on all the time. 
I'm also wary of the turbo charger, I'm using it for now but I've always heard that quick charge stuff lowers the lifespan of your battery due to heat and all that. If anyone has any insight for me on any of this I would appreciate it, I think I may just be too cautious but wanted to be sure before I dropped some money on a mod or a new charger.

I am just as cautious as you are, but either way you'll be fine. The turbo charger is the one that comes with the phone so I can't imagine the manufacturer putting out something that is detrimental to their own product.
As far as the battery mod is concerned, if the Force battery wasn't so good I would use it all the time. I first had the regular Z and was using the mod 24/7. It worked great, but even with that thin phone felt a tad heavy. With the Force it would definitely be a little heavy for me for use all the time. But it sure is nice to have around for when you might need it.
When I first shopped the Z phones the Moto rep was in the Verizon store. He said the battery mod on the phone 24/7 was absolutely fine.
Yeah, the battery mod should be fine for constant or occasional use. Pretty sweet like that...

I've done research on this and leaving the battery mod on would probably actually help prolong the internal battery life. Batteries last longer when they have more incremental charges than a few long charges. The biggest killer to battery longevity is heat. By charging in shorter bursts, the battery doesn't heat up as much.
Having the battery mod on and set to 80% will effectively trickle charge your phone...keeping the heat level down.

How does the battery mod work ? Charging on a wireless charger does the mod charge first then charge the phone? is there a on off switch or its always charging the phone when connected until its dead?
thanks

The phone charges first and then the mod thereafter. No, there is no switch - the mod kicks in automatically either right away (when the phone starts discharging from 100%) or when the phone battery gets to 80% (there is a setting for this). The 80% setting is supposed to extend the life of the Moto Mod.

thread.text:
Motorola has a solid relationship with Verizon.
Their options were: give exclusivity to Verizon or try to work with AT&T and T-Mobile and Verizon without Verizon getting upset.
Moto Mods needed a retail presence.

I kind of think the exclusivity could work this time around. The phones have received a huge amount of positive press.
They'll get all that press again with the international release, release more mods, which it appears they'll do, and it could be a win.

Exactly. I use my JBL more than anything else, and I was very glad to have the Tumi battery when we lost power twice this summer. I can't imagine getting the projector even if the price came way down because it doesn't interest me, but I know a couple of people who can't wait to get it. Different needs I guess!

There might be a pretty decent market for mods. Keep in mind that:
A) Verizon sells a lot of phones, and the Z and Z Force are going to be among their most-pushed.
B) Only the Force is Verizon exclusive (once the standard Z and Z Play launch soon)
C) Lenovo will be pushing these phones a lot in markets other than the US
D) Lenovo has indicated that future phone models will support the same mods
Don't get me wrong, I'm a little iffy on how the mods will do, but I do think they have a chance at being reasonably popular & successful.
The market for mods will hear up once the Z and Z Play are released to the general public.

title: I think the Tumi Battery has a much stronger connection than the Incipio Battery

thread.text: I've realized I guess through trial and error that the Tumi Battery Mod has a stronger connection than than the Incipio. I've wrapped both twice. The Tumi Battery worked perfectly every time. I decided to change it over to red as it's my preferred color for the case back. Both times I've wrapped the incipio I of course wrapped it just the same as the Tumi and it would not connect even though it was attached to the Force. Nothing at all was in the way of the connectors on either battery so I have to assume for some odd reason the Tumi must have a stronger device to device connection. I wrapped both to have very minimal material that actually wraps behind the cast. Almost to where it's barely around the edges. Anyway here is my Tumi in Red modded and now with a much better texture for grip
Sorry. Meant to add that the pic is the Tumi. Now in red and not slippery at all.

I originally had the Tumi. Returned it and bought the Incipio because I liked how it felt in my hand better. But I felt both were equally strong. 
Let's be honest.... They both are probably made the exact same place by the same company. Verizon store mentioned morphie actually making them, but I have no idea if that's true.

thread.text: Saw this on Incipio site:

Anyone have a particular mod you wish you see? Here are a few of my own:
* Photographer quality camera attachment like enhanced optical zoom, telephoto, wide angle, etc
* Specialized optics like Thermal, NV, IR, etc...
* Wireless charging
* Fitness oriented backplate with the appropriate sensors
That's a pretty good list. I wouldn't mind a dynamic "shell" that is a live wallpaper on the back with images/video you want.

The battery mods will have an option for wireless charging if you pay ten dollars extra. There's no reason the battery mods shouldn't have a kickstand like the jbl speaker mod. 
The photography attachment is quite likely, although it may be very pricey.

replies.text:
I think that the price of mods could be what makes or breaks them. The possibilities are endless with regards to what could be developed, and I think that in general the idea is quite exciting. But I don't think that many people will be willing to spend a vast amount of money on a mod. Useful, decent quality mods that can be sold for a reasonable price is what manufacturers should be aiming for to give the idea a chance of taking off and ultimately being a potential success. If they end up being gimmicky and/or too expensive I think the concept may fade into obscurity like many other attempts at innovation. I think that would be a shame as mods have great potential if they are approached in the correct way.

title: I modified a Style Shell and battery pack Moto Mod! (PICS)

thread.text:
I'm about to modify one of the Z Force's Battery Mod Back. Modding a Mod lol. Funny. This is 3m 1080 Ply material. I actually taught myself how to wrap with this material when I modified some of my dash components in my last truck I had. Once I'm done, if wrapped right, it will look like stock or it came that way. This particular material is by far the best I've found. You can buy a kit of this material at AutoZone. Comes in several color options. I've got it in metallic blue, Red, stainless steel, and black carbon fiber colors. I went ahead a bought the other battery mod at best buy which is the Incipio version. I already have the Tumi version. I'm going to mod the Incipio to this Red color. I'll post a pic of the finished modification in just a bit. I'm about to get my hair dryer and knock this mod out. Something different and unique which was what drew me to this phone in the first place. I enjoy taking something and making it my own. Here's a before pic.
Posted via the Android Central App

Here is the finished product. Looks pretty good. I may re-do it as I see a couple of minor imperfections but overall it turned out well. Looks cool on the phone also. I'll grab my iPhone and post a pic of attached to the Force in a bit. The material is so good that you can even still read the Incipio on the case. The best part is this material leaves no residue and can be taken off easier than installed just back to its original state without ever knowing it was on there.
Posted via the Android Central App

I should practice with some of this. I have a vinyl cutter, but have mainly used cheap vinyl for basic signage & such. I'd like to learn wrapping odd shapes. Any reason you're only using a hair dryer, and not a heat gun?

replies.text:
When I first was learning how to become decent at the hobby, a guy who did it for a living told me just a small hairdryer at full blast is plenty enough heat to shape and mold the material. One thing of note. Even the hairdryer can get it too hot and you can actually pull too hard shaping it and it will tear or rip. Biggest tip I can give is get the 1080 Ply and 3m only. He stressed that to me and I at first didn't listen and 3m hands down once applied looks like paint and never bubbles or peels. Cheap material won't make it two weeks before loosing it's perfect stock like look. 3m will remain as it looks until you decide to remove it.
Posted via the Android Central App

Totally agree the 1080 is a superior product, and the right thing to use on this & other projects. I've thought about trying a car wrap, but haven't been brave enough yet. I mainly try to make sure the cheaper vinyl is being used on glass or other hard surfaces where the vinyl could be removed with a razor blade and chemicals for the adhesive, and doesn't need to be stretched, etc.

thread.text:
Okay here is my finished and final product. Initially I did the battery but decided to remove it and mod the ugliest fake wood ever lol. Turned out perfect. Looks just like the Blue one. I pictured both to show how real it looks. The only way you would know would be if you took it off and looked at the back. I've got several other colors in this material so I'm sure I'll post some more pics soon with some other cool colors.

When it comes to the curves and corners you have cut the material, heat, mold the first cut and then heat and mold the other cut. When you cut it, cut directly at the center of the curve or corner. Then stretch heat and pull tightly to make it look seamless.

title: A couple thoughts on the speaker mod.

thread.text:
I got the speaker mod for free from Best Buy, don't know if I would have spent my on money on it because I have a decent Bluetooth speaker already. 
The speaker does sound good and gets loud enough I can hear it with no problem when I'm in the shower. 
But I'm here to talk about the battery in the mod. The speaker mod has its on battery, the notification bar let's you know how much battery it has. I wanted to see if the speaker mod would also charge the phone if it is connected. So I left the mod on the phone over night to see. No. The speaker mod does not charge they phone at all. 
The speaker mod has a USB C connection on the back of it to charge while off of the phone. But once again I wanted to know if I could charge it while it is on the phone. So I plugged the phone in with the speaker mod attached to the phone. It charged both the phone and the speaker mod. 
So 
1. The speaker mod will not charge the phone. 
2. The phone will charge the speaker mod.

I guess it makes sense that the battery is for the speaker itself and not for the phone. I mean, you have to power a speaker somehow. Either it has it's own battery, it has a cord, or it gets power from the phone - those are the only choices. At least it doesn't drain the phone battery (unless it does so after the mod battery is dead? Can't imagine I'll ever try to find out, lol). Good to know it can't be used as a charger/battery pack in a pinch.

replies.text:
Yeah just figured I would try it out to see and then pass on the info so everybody would know. 
I wish it would have been a free battery mod instead, but I will use it.

thread.text:

The stand is also counter to the direction to the sound since the stand points it in downward angle. It sounds better pointed in upward angle, but the design results in a counterintuitive placement. The option to use the speaker mod remote from the phone would have been great.
Still nice mod.

replies.text: Tell them to look under the Pre-Order option in BEAST. Its there.

thread.text:
I don't really need a new phone, my almost three year Droid Maxx in is good shape and does everything I need it to.
But I thought if I could really get a Z for an dollar, why not do it.
I when to Best Buy and asked if it's really one dollar, yes they said.
No hidden costs? No increase to my monthly bill? That's correct they said.
Okay, sign me up. They put all of my info into the system and just before he was ready to put the trigger he says there is a couple of things that I need to tell you. There is going to be a $40 activation fee. I did expect that so I said, okay I can live with that. Then he says that your line access fee in going to go up $20/month for 24 months. This is becaue that line is off contract and I am currenty paying $20/month, the on contract price is $40/month. 
I said hold on you told there was no addition costs, that one dollar just turned into $521. That's a lot on money for something I don't really need. He mentioned that I might be better off going with the $17/month payment plan since it doesn't change the access fee. But either way it was way more than I planned on spending. I told him I was sorry but, please cancel the order. He said that he understood.

replies.text: wow... they slipped that one by me. Grrr...

thread.text: I understand you canceling. But the 20 access fee is for being off contract right. If you were getting the device for 1 dollar I assume it was to sign a contract right so why the fee. That doesn't make sense unless I missed something.
Yeah, I have a $25 discount per line for being out of contract so I'd have to go for the discount on the device payment plan. They're going to get you one way or the other.

Agreeing to the 2y contract changes the access fee from $20 to $40/month for 24 months. That's how they get you to pay for the phone. I knew something wasn't right when the choice was $17.67/month verses one dollar. BTW if you choice the payment plan you have to pay the sales tax on the full prices up front.

I was very strongly tempted to return mine, because the extra $20/mo cost wasn't mentioned to me at all. It makes a $100 (+$40 activation that they *did* mention) phone a $580+$40 phone (though more like $548 total cost with my wife's Verizon discount through her work). That's not a terrible price for how good the phone is, but feeling deceived sucks. It also baffles me how anyone would pay the $300 +$20/mo 2yr contract price for the Force through Verizon...

I bought the Z Force for $99, and the confirmation page and email both clearly say "These new charges will be added to your carrier bill and do not include all taxes, fees and surcharges. Discount or data plan changes previously messaged will be applied to your plan." AND THEN BLANK. Nada. No charges listed.
Of course, now when I look at my plan details on VZW, my line access fee jumped from $20/mo to $40. That's unacceptable. I'd have been better off going with the payment plan and saved $8/mo. I'm trying to talk Verizon out of it - that's an undisclosed fee, which is not exactly legal. But barring that, I'm taking it back and then buying it again on payment plan. The speaker is awesome, as is the phone, but that's too much.

I have an old Nationwide Talk&Text share 1400 plan. Have 3 lines on it, two with UDP and one with a TDP. The TDP was the line I updated, it was out of contract. Got the Z Force for $99.99 with the free speaker. All three lines are $9.99 Line Access Fee. And my plan still shows $9.99 fee with the new two year contract.
Well the projector mod is pretty awesome. Just streamed a baseball game on the side of a camper. Everybody was amazed with the picture and asked what phone it was. Really cool and easy.

title: Do you trust in the longevity of the Mods?

thread.text:
As an overall concept, I think the Moto Mods are an excellent execution of modularity. The simplicity of swapping Mods plus the ability for them to support some really powerful functions is very, very promising. One of the things that has the potential to enhance or detract from the concept, though, is being able to use Mods over the life of more than one phone. A $300 projector is hard to justify, but if you know you'll be able to use it on your next several phones over the course of 5+ years, that starts getting easier to justify.
I recall Lenovo stating that they would make the mods & future phones such that this could happen, but I find myself having trouble trusting that they'll really fulfill that promise in a meaningful way. I could see them making next year's phones compatible, but then changing the design. Since I tend to be on a 2 year replacement cycle, that would ruin any re-use.
Do you think they'll make the mods re-usable over several generations of phones? Do you think it matters? Do you think they might go back on their statement of making more compatible phones if sales of Mods are underwhelming?
It's hard to trust their promises and especially with the cost of the projector that would be frustrating in two years if it's not compatible with the current model.
The 2017 Moto Z is almost certainly in development today. I would expect the mods to work on the 2016 Z and 2017 Z at a minimum. After that who the heck knows.

I think next year's mods and phones will work with this years. And that's about it. Also, I no longer trust Moto at all. I believe that they have good intentions for how this is going to work, but are they really committed to an indefinite period where all of their phones HAVE to be 5.5" and the exact same dimensions as the Z series? How could they be?
They already announced that they will be compatible with next year's Z devices. Beyond that there are no guarantees (even working with next year's devices is a "soft" guarantee IMO).
My Droid Maxx says "no."

replies.text:
